awd_titl_txt: Functional logic of neural circuits: diamonds in the rough
awd_abstract_narration:
One of the pressing challenges to understand large and complex nervous systems is to map how and for what purpose neurons communicate at the lowest level. One-way researchers have made great progress is by recording enormous amounts of information about the neuronal connections, circuits, neural activity, behavior and even genomic structure of smaller nervous systems of some model systems, such as the nematode, fruit fly, or zebrafish. However, all this detailed information has not yet led to satisfying and deeper insight into important questions relevant to understanding the human brain. For example, how do circuits of neurons process, encode, store, and retrieve information? To address such questions, it is important to develop conceptual and theoretical frameworks of the functional logic of brain circuits that go beyond the current computational models. This award will bring together neuroscience pioneers from different fields, including experimental, computational, and theoretical disciplines to define the most important topics and questions to address this challenge.

The organizers will produce and lead a workshop on the Functional Logic of Neural Circuits. The workshop will take place in two phases, a virtual meeting followed by an in-person meeting four months later, in Puerto Rico. In the first phase, the participants will bring up questions and map out the gap among the diverse fields intersecting these disciplines. They will collect ideas from diverse researchers, gauge interest, and solicit feedback and collective input from forward thinkers in these areas to lay ground for the second phase. In a second phase, participants will identify concrete research directions and opportunities that, if pursued, can initiate new conceptual developments that will lead to new breakthroughs in our understanding of the functional logic of neural circuits. The specific topic of the workshop, namely the functional logic of neural circuits offers an opportunity to impact not just our understanding of nervous systems, large or small, but also inform the development of artificial systems with the robustness and flexibility of living organisms. Finally, this workshop aims to not only bring together scientists to identify difficult problems at interdisciplinary interfaces, but to also train a young and diverse generation of diverse scientists to collaborate at the frontiers of neuroscience.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The study of the functional logic of neural circuits occupies a gap that could be filled with a specific funding mechanism.

 The workshop was organized in two phases: a two-day virtual meeting in June 11-12, 2021 (Phase 1), followed by a three-day in person meeting in San Juan (PR) in February 23-25, 2022 (Phase 2). 570 pre-registered attendees logged-in during Phase 1, including 21 speakers and 4 organizers. Phase 2 included 20 in person and 16 remote participants.

 Phase-1. The first meeting was designed to bring up challenges and questions and to map out the knowledge gaps among the diverse fields intersecting these disciplines. It resulted in presentation of original research, and opinions on knowledge gaps and the state of neural circuits research. We collected ideas from diverse researchers, gauged interest, and solicited feedback and collective input to lay the foundation for the second phase.

 Challenges. The recurring themes, experimental and theoretical gaps, and challenges that we identified, motivated us to organize the second phase around four themes. The four prompt questions, inspiring discussions on those themes were: 1) How will massive datasets of neuronal connectivity, activity, and behavior impact the progress in systems neuroscience? 2) What is required to combine theory, computation, and experiments on the functional logic of neural circuits? 3) Can data variability in massive datasets be dealt with or harnessed to explain features of neural circuits? 4) What is the best level for comparing neural circuits of different species?

 

Phase-2. The second, in-person, meeting resulted in presentation of original data, evaluation of state of the field achievements and shortcomings, discussions about possible solutions. We identified three concrete research directions and opportunities that, if pursued, can address these challenges and lead to new breakthroughs in our understanding of the functional logic of neural circuits.

 Recommendations. We suggest that endeavors to explain the function of highly accessible, compact neural circuits, within the constraints of their known connectivity, activity, and behavioral output, transform our understanding and lead towards new directions of research promising to reveal principles in neuroscience and animal behavior. While there are programs that are tangential or supportive of these studies, there is a gap that could be filled with a new, specific, funding mechanism, namely Functional logic of neural circuits (FLN).

 Scientific Community. The meetings and associated interactions fostered interdisciplinary relationships across disciplines and neuroscience fields. The interest in the function of neural circuits has been the intersection of a variety of model systems and experimental and theoretical research approaches. We recognize a need to establish a formal home for this budding community and we plan to organize meetings, at the same venue with the same core participants, to address this need.
